channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Marketplace Dispute in Central China Turns Deadly
item.description: News reports said a dispute between two food vendors in Changsha escalated, leaving five people stabbed to death and one man shot and killed by the police.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard near the site of a fatal stabbing incident in Changsha, Hunan Province.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Social Media App Blocks Prominent Chinese Accounts
item.description: The accounts that have been suspended on WeChat included several that had gained wide followings as independent sources of news and information in China.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Commuters in a subway station in Shanghai checked their mobile devices.

item.title: India Ink: India Welcomes Dismissal of Visa Fraud Case Against Diplomat
item.description: The United States District Court in New York dismissed a case against Devyani Khobragade after determining that she had diplomatic immunity at the time of her federal indictment.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Devyani Khobragade, an Indian diplomat, after her return to New Delhi on Jan. 10. Ms. Khobragade was arrested in New York last year on charges of lying to the United States government to obtain a visa for her housekeeper, who prosecutors said had been paid far less than New York State’s minimum wage.

item.title: India Ink: High Court Upholds Death Penalty in Delhi Gang Rape Case
item.description: The judges said a strong message needed to be sent to “the perpetrators of grotesque and ghastly crimes against women.”
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: Protesters outside a court in New Delhi on Thursday demanding the death sentence for all those accused in the December 2012 gang rape of a medical student, including a defendant who was a juvenile at the time.

item.title: Tony Benn, Leftist Icon in Britain, Dies at 88
item.description: Mr. Benn, a passionate figure in the Labour Party, renounced a hereditary peerage to remain in the House of Commons.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Tony Benn, an icon of the British left, pictured in 2011 in London.

item.title: Kerry Arrives in London for Crisis Talks on Crimea
item.description: As Moscow orders more military exercises on Ukraine’s border, Secretary of State John Kerry is meeting the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, to try to de-escalate the confrontation.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: For Foreign Journalists in Beijing, It’s All About Asking the Right Question
item.description: A news conference with the Chinese prime minister and foreign journalists each year is broadcast worldwide, but is actually staged, with the complicity of many of the largest news organizations in Western journalism.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Li Keqiang of China took questions that had been pre-approved at a news conference at the close of the National People's Congress on Thursday.

item.title: Amid Preparations, Mediator Says Syria Vote Would Doom Talks
item.description: Lakhdar Brahimi said there were many signs that Syria’s government was planning an election, though that would be counterproductive for talks.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Why Do Men Dominate Chinese Politics? Because They’re ‘Just Too Superb’
item.description: The National People’s Congress has slightly more women than in previous sessions, but women still remain a rarity at the top levels of Chinese politics. This gender gap might be due to a “quality” issue, some female delegates said.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Delegates took part in the closing of the National People's Congress on Thursday. Women make up 23.4 percent of the rubber-stamp legislature, and only 4.9 percent of the ruling Communist Party's Central Committee.

item.title: Scores Reported Killed in Village Raids in Nigerian Land Conflict
item.description: A lawmaker in Nigeria’s Katsina State said a group of gunmen on motorbikes, thought to be ethnic Fulani herdsmen, went on a “killing spree.”
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Ukraine Premier Makes Plea at the U.N.
item.description: The interim prime minister, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, sought to rally support for a Security Council resolution criticizing the Russian moves on Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Interrogation of Bin Laden Relative Is Recounted
item.description: During testimony Thursday, an F.B.I. agent describes the interrogation of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a close associate of Osama bin Laden, as “a respectful, relaxed conversation.”
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:credit: AL-JAZEERA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Toronto’s Mayor Is Challenged on the Left
item.description: Olivia Chow, a left-leaning politician, resigned from Parliament this week to open her campaign to replace Rob Ford in the election set for October.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: High & Low Finance: A Review of Banks in Europe Gets Results
item.description: UniCredit’s announcement of a 15 billion euro loss is seen as an attempt to get out in front of a European Central Bank review of large banks.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD NORRIS
item.media:description: Remarks by Federico Ghizzoni, UniCredit’s chief, suggested regulatory indecision on accounting.

item.title: Russia Blocks Web Content Amid Tension Over Ukraine
item.description: Russia’s general prosecutor ordered three websites and a blog closed, saying they encouraged “illegal activities and participation in public events held in violation of the established order.”
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: The Lede: Former U.S. Ambassador Confronts Russian Network’s Editors Over Reporting on Crimea
item.description: Michael McFaul, the former United States ambassador to Russia, told the editor of the Russian government’s overseas broadcast network Russia Today, that he refused to keep “pretending that RT is a news organization.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: In Cambodia, Voicing the Struggle
item.description: Mam Sonando, described by his supporters as Cambodia’s only truly independent radio broadcaster, says he is fighting to “protect people who have been victimized.”
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Luc Forsyth for The New York Times.
item.media:description: Mam Sonando, at a birthday celebration, has been arrested three times over reports on his Beehive Radio program that offended the government.

item.title: Turkish Leader Deplores Unrest, Calling Demonstrators ‘Fakers’
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan accused protesters of trying to stir up chaos ahead of local elections.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Listening Post: Absence of U.S. Envoy in Dublin Looms Over White House St. Patrick’s Day
item.description: The Obama administration has not nominated an ambassador to Ireland since the last one left in 2012, and the delay has bruised feelings. The Irish premier is expected to raise the issue during a White House visit Friday.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: U.S. Takes Back Seat in Malaysian Jet Inquiry
item.description: Some of the world’s foremost experts on crash investigations are in Kuala Lumpur, but technically only to assist the Malaysian government, and they are saying nothing.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: World Briefing: El Salvador: Officials Confirm Ex-Guerrilla’s Victory
item.description: El Salvador’s electoral tribunal on Thursday confirmed that a former guerrilla commander during the country’s civil war emerged from Sunday’s presidential election with the most votes.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: African States to Send Truce Monitors
item.description: East African states agreed on Thursday to send troops to South Sudan by mid-April to help enforce a cease-fire deal between government forces and rebels, the chief mediator in peace talks said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Members of Wedding Party Are Killed in Blast
item.description: A car bomber detonated explosives at an army checkpoint on a bridge in Anbar Province on Thursday, killing at least 16 people, including security officers and members of a wedding party.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Buenos Aires Journal: Soaring Prices Fuel Frustrations Among Weary Argentines
item.description: Since the peso was devalued, Argentines have grappled with one of the world’s highest inflation rates, tilling the ground for social unrest, including a strike by schoolteachers and police sit-ins.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:credit: Anibal Greco for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fruit and vegetable seller waited for customers at Mercado San Telmo in Buenos Aires, where rising prices have become a wearying part of daily life.

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: North Korea Says It Has No Ties to Rogue Ship
item.description: North Korea denied any responsibility for an oil tanker that loaded crude from a rebel-held port in Libya and eluded attempts to seize it.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
